utterances.utterance: -- this is fortune.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go, Geraldo. Go drill.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This is a fortune could be made here. It's one thing when oil was $30 a barrel. Now it's $200 --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they have to let them do it. They have to let them do it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that they -- there's plenty of leeway. And I think a lot -- I go back to the Permian Basin which I know Midland-Odessa --you know, that there's so much oil there. There's so many rigs where the last time I was there with a buddy at the campus of the University of Texas. There's so many rigs that are just sitting there. They're not using them because the market didn't demand it. Now, the market is demanding it. Now, if they can make a buck, it's all about -- it's all about money. Forget about politics. It's all about money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is it all about money or is it about supply?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It's all about the fact that this administration has no strategy. All they do is react. They have no plan. They never had a plan. All they can do is blame Russia or blame Trump or blame somebody else. The truth is that, Geraldo, if these prices have been going up since Joe Biden came in, we were energy independent, all was well, the price of gas - - and we've been over this a million times, the price of gas was affordable. And then he comes in and he's got this green energy of policy. And even the guy who said, you shouldn't be driving that big black truck, you should be -- reconsider a Tesla, the guy who builds Tesla and says drill baby drill, OK. And in the end, you know, what we've got -- or we've got -- it's not just - - it's not just the Keystone, which is really the pipeline that can bring the oil down, it's about the fact that everything in this administration doesn't allow for drilling. It's slow-walking permits, it's slow-walking all of the policies in the right of ways and the roads to the lease, and the supply and labor shortages. There was no planning. That's why we're in this mess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Greg, now, the president called the Saudis. The Saudis wouldn't pick up the phone, wouldn't take his call.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow. There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It happened to you before. It happens a lot. No one takes your calls.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When I tried to get reservations for you at the restaurant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I actually got in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, you did?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did. Yes. It was a mistake though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Applebee's loves you. This does --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Olive Garden.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. This exposes a flaw in the most left-wing ideas which is that they have a goal which is a green -- 100 percent green environment, but they don't have a system to get there. So, it leaves us in a quandary when they cut -- when they remove the solution which is drilling because they have no real replacement. So, you end up going after dictators' oil instead of our own. And once again, the hashtag replaces real action. They probably worked in that alliterative Putin hashtag for months, but you get -- you get the feeling that Psaki and from that montage -- this is an ideology of punishment, right? They see the American people as an amorphous blob with no real life or feeling. You know, too bad they don't have a cool job where you never have to pump gas like Jen Psaki. You know, it's like I pump gas - - I pump my own gas up, believe it or not.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: everybody that doesn't live in New Jersey pumps their own gas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I love it that in New Jersey you don't have to pump your own gas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I enjoy too, the gas. I love the smell.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Me too.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, diesel too.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I love -- I love tipping the gas.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, so --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Can I say one thing about Saudi Arabia?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, please.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Saudi Arabia is a miserable country. I mean --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was necessarily.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, no. Saudi Arabia is killing civilians in Yemen -- going back to what I said earlier about my moral failings and not represent -- you know, feeling sorry for the people in Aleppo when they were getting bombed. Saudi Arabia is bombing the hell out of Yemen. They're killing civilians right and left and the world is silent on it because we want Saudi oil. It's pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, we don't actually need Saudi oil. We can just use American oil. We can totally delink ourselves if we wanted to from global oil prices and we could have American prices dominant.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that we should just ask we ourselves should pump and we should ask all of our allies to do it because the global economy is going to need fuel in order to keep going. So, we should do everything we can here but let's get everyone else to do it as well. Let's talk about nuclear, all that. On the hashtag thing, the stupid thing about that is Twitter doesn't even use hashtags anymore. Because they remove the hashtag and they just like pick up on keywords. So, you don't actually need the hashtag.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like they did in bring back our girl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is the -- oh yes, this is the first I've heard of this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, you know -- so, hashtag -- no need to have our hashtag.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what we should be covering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dana's -- that's "ONE MORE THING."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That would be our E block.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's like -- I mean, that's the news you need to know. But the other thing I wanted to mention is OK, so they want you to buy electric vehicles. OK, well, electric vehicles require a battery. One of the things you need to make the battery is nickel. Where do we get nickel? Oh, Russia. And where are the nickel mines being held up? Oh, America. So, you see the pattern that we're seeing here, hashtag pattern.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is funny to watch someone in a very nice outfit sit back and just say hey, you know, just go buy a Tesla company. Go buy an EV. Like that -- like it's that easy.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: And what about the lithium batteries?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: From China.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. All right, I'll be at Applebee's in about an hour. Coming up, Communist China is set to rescue Russia from financial ruin.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What would you order?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Communist China reportedly getting ready to bail out Vladimir Putin. The U.S. and NATO Allies hitting Russia right where it hurts as you know with these harsh sanctions and the banning of Russian blood oil. The Kremlin vowing to fight back saying America has declared an all-out economic war. But then, Russia turns to China and China could be tossing Putin a financial life preserver considering they are, we are told, buying stakes in Russia's energy sector. So, China will just, you know, take up the slack for Russia.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. I mean, these two guys think alike. Of course, they're going to take care of each other. And you know what's amazing?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But are you surprised that they're friends?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I'm not surprised at all. And when he says it's an all-out economic war, Putin, it goes right back to what I was saying and I think it was in the A block when he's talking about the fact that who knows what new hurdler what new standard he's going to use for, you know, triggering him? It's an economic war, so therefore, I'm going to be at war with all of you. But no, I think that -- I think they should be very happy together. But the problem is that if we go to electric vehicles and all that, we're going to have some trouble with lithium and some of the other materials that we need.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: See, I go back to the money thing, Jesse. I think China wants to make money. China is in -- exists to make money and to get more and more powerful. This is very bad for business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, Europe in turmoil and everybody suspicious of the other.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. It is bad for business. But they're going to go in and raid all the commodities out of Russia. They're going to go after their timber and their coal and their oil and their gas. But after commodities, they don't have anything in Russia. And then there -- you look at China -- you look at China and you look at Russia and you think that's disgusting. You don't want to have any association with Russia. And then you're going to have some guy come in, the Chinese, and an act like their sugar daddy, no. So, they're going to face boycotts, they're going to face sanctions. If you're going to come in and deal with the Russians, then you're going to have Western banking institutions say no, you stay over there. So, they're going to have to decide, you know, are they going to delink themselves from the global economy and deal deals with a pariah state that's going bankrupt? Or do they want to, you know, keep propping up their economy with Western cash, and at least try to be seen as a normal stakeholder and not some disgusting, you know, communist regime that's bailing out a war criminal?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What about Taiwan, Dana? What about -- here you have this island. China threatening to take it over the way they took over Hong Kong. But militarily, they want to take over Taiwan. Will this give China the feeling that America is a toothless tiger anyway, that now is the time to take Taiwan?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it is interesting that President Xi has this opportunity to see how it would go. So, he told Putin to wait until after the Olympics, which tells me also, Xi doesn't think of Putin as an equal at all. He thinks of Putin as subpar. And I think he also thinks that this was pitiful the way that this has gone down, and that it looks awful. And we even heard yesterday that the Germans and the French were talking to the Chinese about figuring out a way to try to find peace talks. I think -- I think that the Chinese look at Putin and think like, if it had gone perfectly according to all the things that Greg mentioned, all the assumption, the four assumptions that Putin had, that all of that had worked out perfectly, I think Beijing would have said, well, then next fall, after our big communist meeting, maybe we just go ahead and figure out a way to take Taiwan. That might have gotten harder now. But one of the things that China will figure out in addition to the economic things that you've mentioned, is that the oil will be available to them to buy. They have a voracious appetite. And they've been helping Iran for many years get out of the situation with the sanctions for the rest of the world. China doesn't care, they'll buy their oil. So, there might be a way for Putin to at least keep afloat in some way. But I agree that's not a very attractive dance partner that China is looking at here.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And yet, Greg, when you look at the map, if you ever map at home, folks, take a look at China and Russia together. They take -- they take up an awful lot big hunk of the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what, this is what -- I hope -- I hope Dana is right. But it's not just the world, it's the final frontier. I don't want a partnership between China and Russia because they're going to need to be partners if we're talking about space or owning that space, because basically, that should be ours. But if those two guys get together, we're screwed. But you're right. You know, if Russia does end up hooking up with China, they have to be China's puppet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How can it be anything else? Because you -- if they have all your bank -- they have all your bank stuff, right? Because you're going to do the bank stuff, they're going to buy your oil, like what can Putin do. Putin is basically going to be holding his jock.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They also have 10 times the population of Russia.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's exactly what I was going to say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I said holding his jock. I don't even know what that means.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, you took the words right out of my mouth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sorry about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other issue is the Arctic Circle --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's an ugly --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- where there's a lot of oil and there will be a dispute. I'm fascinated by that talk.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The jock talk is an ugly visual. Coming up, a terrifying warning on what a frustrated Vladimir Putin could do next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: U.S. intelligence officials warning Vladimir Putin is growing angry and frustrated as the Ukrainian resistance holds up. Russia losing about 50 military vehicles a day including tanks. And now American intelligence thinks Putin could use drastic measures if he can't take Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BURNS, DIRECTOR, CIA
utterances.utterance: Russian doctrine holds that, you know, escalate to deescalate. Russian leadership considering the use of tactical nuclear weapons. But I stressed that that's only in that specific circumstance that you described, a direct military conflict between NATO and Russia.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And the White House now warning that Russia could use chemical or biological weapons in Ukraine. Do you think he would do that, Dana? I think he would lose just about any --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Any support.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Any support or any argument against taking him out as, you know, other countries.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You made some good points in the A book about how he will be desperate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so, I don't think that we do know. And I think William Burns, the CIA director is probably the most competent and valuable member of the President's cabinet, and that maybe he should have gone to Poland. And I think that the reason -- you know, he said is very specific, right? It's like, if this happens, and only this happens, and he's answering a question from a member of Congress. He's not saying this is going to happen, Putin is about to do this. And so, I think that we have to maybe be cautious, be aware that it is a possibility, but not worry too much at the moment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Judge?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You know what's interesting as I'm looking at this? The top U.S. intelligence agency offered a sobering assessment of him in how his invasion into Ukraine can affect the safety and security of the United States. And although we're really not in this war, we are not, is he going to react because he's losing so badly? And he is losing badly on the world stage and he is being condemned every day. I mean there isn't a human being alive that I know of who isn't opposed to what's going on with, you know, a medical building and hospitals being bombed, civilians being killed, people's lives being upended. And if you are as desperate as Putin is to either impress Xi Jinping or, you know, to expand his own territory, then he's going to resort to what he resorted to in Aleppo and in Chechnya. I mean, I can imagine him doing that. Then the question is, what do we do? Where -- when do we get triggered? We keep worrying about triggering him. He's going to trigger himself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Geraldo, there is a lesson here is that -- I mean, a good lesson and that if you invade a neighbor, the world will destroy your country. I mean, I think that's a fairly new thing. I mean, what we're seeing is such a speedy kind of dramatic response.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You listed the failures of Putin. And one of the failures was his inability to foresee that Germany and France would shake off the doldrums and get it together and back the assailed country, the beleaguered country, Ukraine. But that's not what I'm worried about. You know, that's what's happening now. What I worry about is the guy facing abject defeat and disappointment and rebellion within his ranks and all those dead bodies coming home, all those kids all those draftees coming home dead, you know. And, you know, he's looking at his butler, waiting for his butler to kill him. Doing a nuke -- a nuke is the thing that -- that's the nightmare. When you're at my age, that's where you grew up in the Cold War. This is the Cold War II. What's this crazy nutjob going to do when he's in the corner? He's like -- he's like a rat. He's like a rat -- cornered rat. What's he going to do? If he -- if he -- there's no doubt that if Hitler had a button at the end of World War II, and he knew -- and the Russians were coming into Berlin, he would have pushed the button and nuke the world, destroyed the world. There's no doubt about that in my mind. And I think about Putin now. Is he -- is he going to have the button at the end of the world?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hope they gave him a fake button. That would be nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, you know, you should be CIA director.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe that would --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just came up with that on the fly. Give him a fake button.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe that was the button Hillary gave. Remember?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's right. The reset button.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, the reset.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, if he is that crazy when he's in a corner, and he's that desperate to use a tactical nuke, we can't put him in the corner.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why when NATO gets involved, that's when the tactical nuke comes out. We -- that's why I think the likelihood of a coup --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- rises when NATO doesn't get involved. Because the minute the situation where NATO gets involved, then that galvanizes Russia, then Russia sees oh, NATO is involved and the Kremlin gets all fired up and it becomes Russia versus NATO. Now, Putin owns this. He owns the Russian economy. He went in. He's destroyed the ruble. Leave it that way. Make him own this. And that's where you want to dance. That's the place you want to dance.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: But he's not going to own it by himself quietly. That's the thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, right, because he's got all the misinformation.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You're talking about totally defeating him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But I think if no one buys Russian oil, and the ruble is worthless --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Chinese are going to buy the Russian oil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, the pipelines don't go to China. They got to ship it. And you can't even get insurance to ship anything now. It can take forever to get it to Beijing. But I don't know. I think, wait it out a little bit longer. Let the sanctions really, really bite harder and just see what happens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And pray.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And pray.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pray for miracles because --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- that's what I think that -- you look, for the miracles. There have been a few. And the really brave, heroic things that are being done and other countries to help the refugees, but find a humanitarian corridor, find a way to help -- get a country that can provide actual humanitarian corridor that is safe. That should be our number one goal overnight. That's what -- that's what -- not Hillary, Kamala Harris should focus on tonight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. There has to be a way to let Putin's inner circle or outer circle know that they are also can be tried for war crimes, because that's a great incentive for them because they still -- they might live and they might live to see their own execution.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was a big day with the bombing of the -- this was a crucial day for the -- for Russia and the West.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, turning point.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I hope you're right. I hope you're right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, more breaking news from Ukraine next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Zelenskyy says millions of people could die if the world does not act now to stop Russian bombings. That happening after a horrific airstrike on a children's hospital today. Let's get to our final thoughts before we turn it over to Bret. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, just to reiterate what I said at the beginning of the show. The options are we go in or we mediate, you know. And I think that we spent -- we spent a lot of time -- we had a lot of powerful politicians in the Ukraine in 2014 and Biden even claimed that he spent more time on the phone with Ukrainian leaders and his own wife. So, if we can meddle, we can mediate. I say we go -- you know, we create a, you know, and A team of sorts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Including Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm on an A team?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, first time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They wouldn't have me on that team. I think that oil prices are going to probably hit 200. And gas prices are going to probably hit six or $7.00 a gallon here in the United States and the President is going to have to make a serious decision and he's not there yet, but he will have to make that decision.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll get there. Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I said yesterday that Zelenskyy could not be killed. Now, his image, his heroism will live forever in the annals of Ukrainian history. But I also think that Putin, by murdering women and children, has gone beyond the pale. He is irredeemable. You can't think of a world with Putin anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Judge Jeanine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you know, I think that in Russia also, I mean, given what he has done to his own people and the fact that many of his own people don't agree with what he's doing, I think that Putin is the persona non grata of the century.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Perhaps forever. All right, that is it for us. "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hi, Bret!
